paths2

Class Rect

  • java.lang.Object
    • paths.Path
      • paths2.Path2
        • paths2.Rect
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IPath, IPath2

    public class Rect
extends Path2
    A rectangle, analgous to Processing's rect() function.
    Author:
    James Morrow [jamesmorrowdesign.com]

    • Constructor Detail

      • Rect

        public Rect(processing.data.JSONObject j)

      • Rect

        public Rect(float a,
            float b,
            float c,
            float d,
            int rectMode)
        Parameters:
        a - the 1st rect argument, whose meaning is determined by the given rectMode
        b - the 2nd rect argument, whose meaning is determined by the given rectMode
        c - the 3rd rect argument, whose meaning is determined by the given rectMode
        d - the 4th rect argument, whose meaning is determined by the given rectMode
        rectMode - Determines the meaning of a, b, c, and d. The rectMode can be CENTER, RADIUS, CORNER, or CORNERS.

        Copy constructor.
        Parameters:

      • trace

        public void trace(Point pt,
                  float amt)
        Description copied from interface: IPath
        A continuous function from real values (floats) to Points.

        Maps a given floating point number from 0 to 1 to a given Point along the perimeter of the Path.
        Specified by:
        trace in interface IPath
        Specified by:
        trace in class Path
        Parameters:
        pt - The Point in which the result is stored.
        amt - A number from 0 to 1.

      • translate

        public void translate(float dx,
                      float dy)
        Description copied from interface: IPath
        Shifts this Path dx units in the x-direction and dy units in the y-direction.
        Parameters:
        dx - The number of pixels to shift the path right.
        dy - THe number of pixels to shift the path down.

      • inside

        public boolean inside(float x,
                      float y)
        Description copied from interface: IPath2
        Returns true if (x,y) is a point within the path (which would imply that this is a closed path) and false otherwise.
        Parameters:
        x - the x of the point
        y - the y of the point
        Returns:
        true if the point is inside the path and false otherwise
